metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of flux observation matrix (automatic meteorological station of No.17) of the MUlti-Scale Observation EXperiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces 2012 (MUSOEXE-12)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the automatic weather station (AWS) measurements from site No.17 in the flux observation matrix from 12 May to 17 September, 2012. The site (100.36972° E, 38.84510° N) was located in an orchard in Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1559.63 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity (HMP45C; 5 m, towards north), air pressure (PTB110; 2 m), rain gauge (52203; 10 m), wind speed and direction (034B; 10 m, towards north), a four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, vertically downward), soil temperature profile (109; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, and -1.0 m), soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, and -1.0 m), and soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates with one below the vegetation and the other between plants, 0.06 m). One of the infrared temperature sensors (IRT_2) was adjusted to a zenith angle of 50° after 6 August.
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and RH_5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), air pressure (press, hpa), precipitation (rain, mm), wind speed (Ws_10 m, m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m, °), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation; W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IR_2, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2 and Gs_3, W/m^2), soil temperature profile (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, and Ts_100 cm, ℃), and soil moisture profile (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, and Ms_100 cm, %).
  The data processing and quality control steps were as follows. (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min; therefore, there were 144 records per day. The missing data were filled with -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) In this dataset, the time of 0:10 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:10; the data were stored in *.xlsx format. (5) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces using remote sensing techniques?
Example.Answer: A challenge mentioned is the limited effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions, as errors in derived component temperatures can occur due to image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to study eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area?
Example.Answer: The HiWATER observation system dataset includes measurements from a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network, with data quality controlled through sensor calibration and processing.

Feature Specification.Question: What features are typically measured in a flux observation matrix for capturing eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, wind speed, humidity, four-component radiations, turbulent fluxes, soil heat fluxes

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of data collected by automatic meteorological stations in eco-hydrological studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, barometric pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil temperature, soil moisture

Quantification.Question: What is the frequency of data collection for meteorological parameters at the Daman superstation?
How many layers of soil moisture and temperature sensors are installed for data collection?
Quantification.Answer: 7 depths for soil moisture sensors, 8 depths for soil temperature probes

Definition.Question: What is a flux observation matrix in the context of eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: A flux observation matrix refers to a system composed of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations used to measure and analyze energy and mass fluxes across different scales within a specified area. It provides critical data for studying eco-hydrological processes, particularly in heterogeneous landscapes.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations are crucial in eco-hydrological research as they address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. By employing hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, multiscale observations enable the capture of data across various spatial and temporal scales, improving the understanding and modeling of complex interactions within ecosystems.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for soil and canopy component temperatures using a thermal infrared camera compare to those using ground-based measurements in estimating evapotranspiration?
Comparison.Answer: The use of a thermal infrared camera allows for the collection of high-resolution thermal images to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures, which are then converted to radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation and emissivities. Ground-based measurements, such as those from the meteorological and eddy covariance systems, provide direct observations of turbulent fluxes and other meteorological parameters. The thermal camera method offers a high-precision approach for separating soil and canopy temperatures, which is crucial for accurately estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in data quality control approaches between multiscale datasets obtained from a flux observation matrix and those from remote sensing instruments during HiWATER?
Comparison.Answer: Both multiscale datasets from the flux observation matrix and remote sensing instruments undergo rigorous quality control processes, including sensor calibration and data processing. The flux observation matrix, which includes eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, focuses on ground-based measurements of fluxes and meteorological variables, while remote sensing instruments like LiDAR and thermal imagers provide hyper-resolution airborne data. Despite these differences, both types of datasets are carefully managed to ensure reliability and accuracy, with data available at platforms such as figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data collection techniques employed in multiscale observation experiments potentially address the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection techniques employed in multiscale observation experiments, such as HiWATER, address the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations by utilizing a hierarchical and nested instrumentation approach. This involves setting up a network of flux observation matrices, eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and eco-hydrological sensors across different landscapes. Additionally, the use of airborne remote sensing tools like LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and multi-angle thermal imagers provides high-resolution data that can capture eco-hydrological processes at various scales. This comprehensive setup allows for the collection of detailed and diverse datasets that can be used to analyze and model complex interactions in heterogeneous environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of accurately estimating evapotranspiration using the two-source energy balance model in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the heterogeneous nature of the landscape, which includes a mixture of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistances to energy exchange. Additionally, the two-source model requires parameters and observations that cannot be easily obtained from operational satellite and ground-based data, which limits its application. Errors in surface–air temperature difference and the strong advective environment also affect the model's performance.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a challenge in obtaining multiscale observations for upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge is primarily due to the poor availability of multiscale observations. Progress in this field is hindered because capturing eco-hydrological processes requires data from various scales, which are difficult to obtain. HiWATER addresses this challenge by using a hierarchically nested scale instrumentation approach to collect multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes errors in the measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures using a thermal infrared camera in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in the measurement are primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. Misclassification of soil and vegetation pixels can lead to overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, and uncertainties in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy contribute to these errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the outcomes of implementing a hierarchically nested instrumentation approach in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a hierarchically nested instrumentation approach, as seen in HiWATER, can address the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations. It allows for the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes through comprehensive data collection at different landscape scales, offering valuable insights into oasis-desert interactions and enabling detailed analysis of the eco-hydrological dynamics.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate evapotranspiration estimates using both ground-based measurements and isotopic techniques?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Validating evapotranspiration estimates using both ground-based measurements and isotopic techniques is important to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the estimates, especially in strongly advective and heterogeneous environments. This approach allows for a better separation and validation of evaporation and transpiration components, which is crucial for improving models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in the installation and configuration of meteorological sensors for measuring air temperature, wind speed, and radiation in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In a heterogeneous landscape, meteorological parameters are typically measured using sensors installed at various heights. For example, air temperature and wind speed can be measured at 5 meters above the ground using a combination of sensors. Four-component radiation is measured at 12 meters above the ground, while turbulent fluxes are captured at 4.5 meters using an eddy covariance system. The setup and orientation of sensors, including the direction and height, are critical to obtaining accurate measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps in ensuring quality control and data integrity during the collection and processing of multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control in multiscale eco-hydrological data collection involves several steps. First, sensor calibration ensures that all instruments provide accurate readings. During data collection, continuous monitoring and validation are necessary to detect any anomalies or errors. Data processing includes checking for completeness, removing duplicate or physically unrealistic records, and standardizing time formats. Finally, datasets are generated with careful attention to quality control, ensuring they are suitable for analysis and freely available for further research.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the effective partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration in agricultural regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-resolution thermal cameras and the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model enables effective partitioning by using soil and canopy component temperatures. The TSEB model requires only a single measurement of land surface temperature, which can be obtained from thermal infrared cameras, allowing for accurate estimation of evaporation and transpiration under various vegetation types and conditions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do ground-based measurements complement remote sensing data in validating models for evapotranspiration estimation?
Enablement.Answer: Ground-based measurements, such as those from eddy covariance systems, complement remote sensing data by providing validation for models like the TSEB. These measurements are crucial for accurately estimating energy fluxes and partitioning evapotranspiration into its components, especially in regions with strong advective conditions, as they help to address uncertainties in temperature and radiation measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset collected from a heterogeneous landscape present challenges in accurately estimating evapotranspiration (ET)?
Expectation.Answer: In a heterogeneous landscape, the surface contains a mixture of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange, making it difficult to accurately estimate surface evapotranspiration using one-source models. Additionally, errors in determining component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures can lead to inaccuracies in ET estimation, particularly in strongly advective environments.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a high level of complexity involved in using the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model for estimating evaporation and transpiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: The TSEB model is complex due to the need to accurately calculate multiple resistances and requires parameters and observations that are difficult to obtain from satellite- and ground-based data. This complexity is further exacerbated in heterogeneous landscapes where the separation of soil and canopy temperatures is crucial for reliable estimations, and errors in temperature separation can significantly affect model performance.

Expectation.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations critical for advancing research on eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: The availability of multiscale observations is critical because eco-hydrological processes occur at various scales and are influenced by interactions between different landscape features. Progress is hindered by the lack of such observations, and multiscale datasets provide comprehensive data to address challenges such as capturing the interactions in oasis-desert systems and understanding the spatial variability of these processes.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges and limitations faced in multi-scale data collection for eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The field highlights that upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces is challenging due to the poor availability of multiscale observations. Despite the use of hierarchically nested scales and diverse instrumentation, capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes remains difficult, largely due to the variability in landscape features and the complexity of accurately measuring interactions between different environmental components.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand why multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes are so challenging to obtain.
Assertion.Answer: Progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a grand challenge addressed by the HiWATER experiment through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand what kind of data collection method is used to capture interactions in an oasis-desert system.
Assertion.Answer: To capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert system, instruments were arranged on hierarchically nested scales, including a sparse network with a superstation in the oasis, four EC towers, and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations in different surrounding landscapes. Additionally, intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential challenges in accurately measuring evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces using ground-based methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is particularly challenging. The major challenges include the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy, the uncertainty in surface–air temperature differences, and errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures. Errors in image classification, particularly in arid regions, and uncertainties in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy also contribute to the challenges in using ground-based methods for evapotranspiration measurement.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of data collection strategies for multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection strategies involve the use of a flux observation matrix including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Additionally, a network of eco-hydrological sensors for soil moisture and leaf area index is used, along with hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer. Intensive observations are carried out during specific periods, and instruments are arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, including oasis-desert interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methodologies used to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration components using remote sensing and ground-based data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies involve using the TSEB model, which requires the calculation of soil and canopy component temperatures using thermal infrared images. The visible and NIR images are classified into soil and canopy pixels, and the directional brightness temperatures are extracted. The Craig–Gordon model is applied to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using ground-based measurements, such as air temperature, wind speed, humidity, and radiometric temperatures. The data from these measurements are validated against surface radiometric temperatures and stable isotope techniques to improve accuracy.
